He's joined by FOUR OTHER MEN, ALL BLACK CLAD - HEAVILY ARMED with BODY ARMOR!  Lorenz stares out at the bank, a last moment of peace. Simultaneously, ALL FOUR DOORS OPEN and...  7    EXT. LOBBY - AMERICAN NATIONAL BANK                             7A  PATRONS in line, wait impatiently. A SECURITY GUARD in the corner yawns. TELLERS count out cash, access accounts on COMPUTERS.  GRAINY SECURITY CAMERA IMAGES depict an average, business day. THE CALM BEFORE THE STORM.

Dialogue: Can we get back to work?

Speaker: marnie
Dialogue: We got passports, sun tan lotion, Bermuda shorts, thong bikini, hopefully hers and this...

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Must be a fifty large there easy.    His cut?

Speaker: marnie
Dialogue: You'd think, right?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: It's not?

Speaker: marnie
Dialogue: Don't put words in my mouth, but... Two things jump out here. First, each bank branch has their own money bands. This is not American National's. After a little checking, it belongs to Pacific Savings of Seattle.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: That sounds familiar.

Speaker: marnie
Dialogue: It should. Four months ago, a half million dollars was stolen in an armed robbery there. Just a smash-n-grab job. They caught the guys a day later, recovering about $400,000. Those guys have been in lock up since and their trial's still pending. Which leads us to point number two. Do you smell that?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: marnie
Dialogue: When evidence is taken in, any physical contact might affect the ability to lift prints, so, to mark it, we now spray a scented solution directly on the bill.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Is that new?

Speaker: marnie
Dialogue: Wave of the future.   Gotta keep up with the times, Conners.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: So this money's not from our bank.

Speaker: marnie
Dialogue: No. This is the money from the Pacific Savings job and our evidence room.  Now... For a list of things you can put in my mouth.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Do you remember who headed up the Pacific Savings case?

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: I think it was Callo.    Why?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: No reason.     Just thinking out loud.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: When you said it was your "family business" I didn't think... I guess I just didn't connect the dots.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Don't worry about it.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Your father was a hero.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Yes he was.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: At first I thought maybe you were related to the Captain.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: No.   No relation.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: The Captain, he just kind of "discovered" you. Through the academy, to excellent evaluation reports, while

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Something like that.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: That's how he found me.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Maybe we're not as different as you think.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: We found the money.

Speaker: gina
Dialogue: That money was Dwayne's...

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: That money came from our evidence room.

Speaker: gina
Dialogue: I told you. I don't know nothing about a bank robbery. Whatever Damon was into, I didn't know!

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: So, where were you going?

Speaker: gina
Dialogue: Vacation.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: This isn't possession or solicitation, Gina. This is felony-murder one. You could get life.

Speaker: gina
Dialogue: Me!?   I didn't do nothing!

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: It's "I didn't do anything." "Didn't do nothing" is a double negative, infers the positive. The grammar in this country sucks.

Speaker: gina
Dialogue: Then I didn't do ANY-thing!

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: This isn't going away. You want to walk out of here, you tell me something... now.

Speaker: gina
Dialogue: I swear I don't know. Now I'm done talking. I want a lawyer.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: You sure that's what you want?

Speaker: gina
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Fine. Then it's two phone calls I'll make. The first will be to the public defender's office. The second to children's services.

Speaker: gina
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: It's simple... if you insist on a lawyer, I take your kids.

Speaker: gina
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Not like you cared about them anyway. You were ready to fly the coop with "Shit-for-brains."

Speaker: gina
Dialogue: No.   You can't do that.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: I can and I will.

Speaker: gina
Dialogue: Don't.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Tell me what I want to know!

Speaker: gina
Dialogue: I don't know anything.     Please don't take my kids. Please.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Get her some coffee...     Something hot.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You believe her?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: I think for the first time in that girl's life she's telling the truth.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You had to know, once she asked for a lawyer anything she told us would have been inadmissable.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Who would've known? It would've been my word against hers. Who do you think the jury would've believed?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Justice by any means.    Even if you cross the line.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: The only line around here is the `blue line', you cross that one, then you got

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Those serial numbers Marnie faxed me... According to our computers, that money should be downstairs.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Buzz us in.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: You gotta sign first.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: I heard you were back. Kinda liked not having you around, Conners.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Have another donut, Frankie.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: That fat fuck is the sole guardian of the city's biggest source of contraband. Drugs. Weapons. Cash.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You'd have to have some major firepower, not to mention an extra large set of balls to try and knock off a police station.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Not if you were a cop.    You could just walk right in and...

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: ...   Take whatever you want.   Shit.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Here is it. Line seventeen.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Bernie Callo.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Like I said... No one takes anything out of here, unless they sign for it.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: So what...     He showed you a warrant? What?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: He must've.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: You don't remember?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: You know how many times someone signs shit in and out? I see the same guys all the time. I can't remember one instance two weeks ago. But if his signature's there, that means he signed for it. Take it up with him!

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: The money from Richards's place traced back to the Pacific Savings heist a few months ago, a case Callo headed up.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Callo signed the money out of evidence two weeks ago.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: If it's Callo, it would explain how they knew police protocol and how our department operates.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Also explains why he was so pissed this morning about being replaced by Conners. He wanted to be the point so everything went according to plan.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: He doesn't need another reason to be pissed at me.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: What about motive?    Do we have one?

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: Pressure might've been getting to him. He's been getting the cold shoulder from cops since he testified about Pearl Street Bridge.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: No.   Don't buy that.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: He was also getting divorced.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: About a month ago, he told me he and his wife might be splitting. Asked if I knew a lawyer who wouldn't clean him out. I didn't think it was this bad.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: Bernie Callo is a first rate cop.     A boy scout. This doesn't make any sense.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: They never do, Captain.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: Don't act like you're not enjoying this, Conners. I know what you think of him.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Doesn't matter what I think.      Facts here speak for themselves.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: No they don't. We haven't asked the question... Why, if Callo's involved, don't they ask for him at the bank?  They asked for you.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: Jenkins.

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: Blueprints from the bank, schematics, pictures... Also, about a dozen internet articles on the Saudi Prince. Found it behind the furnace.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Well, that's it, right?

Speaker: lorenz
Dialogue: Are you connecting the dots? Are you putting it together? Is the pattern emerging? They wouldn't punish you, but I will.

Speaker: lorenz
Dialogue: Vengeance will be mine, Detective.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Then come and get me you piece of shit.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: What they told Callo was the plan and what the plan really was may be two different things. Clearly this wasn't part of a plan Callo would've agreed with.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You'd think a cop would be smarter.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: As cops we come across every temptation in the book. Money, drugs, power. We'd all like to think we can resist any urge, but... We're not saints.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: So, Callo was involved and now they're dragging you into it. Why?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Man said he wanted vengeance.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Piss anyone off lately?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Me?

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: I just got off the phone with Agent Doyle. After the Charlotte break in, the Prince withdrew all his possessions from every safe deposit box in this country.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Let me get this straight, they didn't touch the cash or the safe deposit boxes. So, they... break into a bank, blow it up, and steal nothing?  Still make sense to you?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Nothing about today makes sense.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: "Return to the earth now if your mind is troubled and your heart is uncertain. For it is by returning to the beginning that we can clearly see the path."

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Don't look at me, he's your find.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: Say that again, Detective?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: We go back to where this all started. We go to the bank.

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: The tapes confirm five bad guys, but since the vault cam blew in the explosion what they did in there was a mystery.

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: I've been through these tapes twenty times already and nothing...

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Shutup.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Wait, hold on a second.   Did you see it?

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: See what?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Go back a little.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Notice the camera angles, they're all fixed. They don't rotate or pan.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: There. Stop. Play it. Look closely, camera five, the vault cam, dominates our attention because of the explosion. But while that's happening, check out Camera two, customer service.

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: Where'd he go?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: He moved it. Changed the angle.    He didn't want us to see something.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: What's in that corner they didn't want us to see?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Are you at all concerned that there's some whacko out there looking to get you?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: If I worried about every threat made against me, I'd never leave the house.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Those are priority one. If he's got a record, I want an I.D. yesterday.

Speaker: forensics technician
Dialogue: I'm on my way.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Dax, can you hack in there and find out what they were doing on this machine?

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: Hack into a nationwide bank's central computer system? Love to.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: What do we do in the meantime?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: You like Italian?

Speaker: italian host
Dialogue: Detective, where you been? Much too long. Sit, sit. I give you best table in house. It'll just be the two?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: No, four.    More are coming.

Speaker: italian host
Dialogue: Wonderful, wonderful. Who's this young man?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: For all intents and purposes... he's Big Brother.

Speaker: italian host
Dialogue: He's your brother?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: italian host
Dialogue: No matter, no matter...     I bring you bottle of house wine!

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: We're still on duty.     No wine.

Speaker: italian host
Dialogue: No wine?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: A little wine.

Speaker: italian host
Dialogue: That's better.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Last time I was here, you said that table in the corner was the "best in the house."

Speaker: italian host
Dialogue: It was. Anywhere you sit becomes best table in house. Now relax, I bring you food.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Shane, what was that thing you said back at the house about "returning to the beginning path" or something?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: It's a Buddhist story.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: We're all ears.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: One day the Buddha found his heart in turmoil. So he retreats to the forest, to the earth, to the base of a great tree and, I'm paraphrasing, but... this elephant comes up and tells Buddha he doesn't like seeing him discouraged.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: He can talk to an elephant?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: He's the Buddha. He's attained the 6th level of consciousness. He's capable of communicating with plants, trees... even rocks.

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: Rocks?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You asked.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Continue.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: The Buddha was troubled so he went back to where he came from, the beginning, to find the path, the answer. So when you hit a dead end, go back to the beginning to find your way. Or something like that.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: We have a genuine philosopher in our midst.

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: You're a Buddhist?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: No. Just something I picked up along the way.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: But you're religious?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Not particularly.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You're all pretty tight.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: We've been through a lot together.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: I guess I just thought... I don't know. With all the trouble he's been in lately, coming back from suspension, everyone would treat him differently.

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: You can't believe what you read or see on TV. If anything, our tie to Conners is stronger. He's one of the best. Even when things got pretty wild today and everyone else panicked, he was in control. That doesn't just happen. He's just that good.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Excuse me.

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: What was the Buddha looking for?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: The divine in himself.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: How long does it usually take to for fingerprints to be ID'd?

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: Hours, maybe days.    We could be waiting a while.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: They got a match.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: I realized something today. Being around you, all that's happened...       I can't... I think I made a mistake.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: It's too late. You've made your choice. Live with it.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: We got a match.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: You got a name?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Chris Lei.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Sonofabitch.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Prick used to work for some big-time software company until they caught him dipping into the company's slush fund. They didn't want the publicity so they didn't press charges. Couple years later, he was busted for looting the pension plans of retired cops. For a genius... he's a fucking moron.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: This was your case. You and York. You made the bust. Why didn't it stick?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: His lawyer put us on trial. Said we were crooked, abusive, that we planted evidence... We were in the midst of the Pearl Street Bridge fallout. Jury bought it. They let him walk and we were the scapegoats.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Was it true?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: The guy was guilty. He was scum. That was the truth.  There's something they don't teach you. The system breaks down. You have to compensate to get results.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: That gives you the right to break the rules?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Break, no.     Bend... if it means justice...     Absolutely.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Another thing they don't teach you.

Speaker: chris
Dialogue: Shit.

Speaker: lorenz
Dialogue: Fare thee well, Chris.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: First day in the city and you've already been shot.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Why don't I "just graze" you with a bullet and see how you feel.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Take five, guys.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Hiya, Damon. How you feeling?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: May I?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You remember me, don't you?  Thought so.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: I was skiing about three years ago. Aspen. Beautiful country. Ever been? Never mind. I hit a mogul, landed on a sheet of ice and slammed into a tree. Broke myself up pretty bad. Kinda like you did today. I was in a hospital bed for three months. Had it not been for... Here it is.  Morphine. Without this stuff, I wouldn't have made it.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Now this IV drip administers a small dosage every minute. Makes you feel relaxed and calm. No pain. But...

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: If I were to inject this whole thing... That would be all she wrote for Damon.

Speaker: richards
Dialogue: You don't have the balls.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: This equipment malfunctions all the time. Overdoses are quite common. Besides, I don't think the DA's going to launch a full-scale investigation over a scum like you.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You don't have to tell us a damn thing. Plead the fifth... roll the dice.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: You fuckin' hypocrite. You give me shit for my interrogating skills... least I don't threaten them with a lethal overdose.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: There's never been a single case in recorded medical history of someone overdosing on 200 milliliters of saline.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Bend, not break. That's what you said, right?

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: He's also the brother of John Curtis, the perp Conners shot at Pearl Street Bridge.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: You never think of the repercussions. The suspect's mother, father... Brother. How your decision affects them.  He had murder in his eyes.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: John Curtis.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: It was pouring. Lights everywhere.       If he had only done what I said.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: But it was not to be.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: My father died when I was twelve. He walked into a liquor store in the middle of a stick up. Guy just opened fire. Never even had time to react. They said he was a hero. Know what

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: So why become a cop?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Finish what he started. Every day he went out, trying to do some good. Help the people who couldn't help themselves, just give'em a chance is what he always said. Didn't always work out right, but he tried. You tried to help save that girl on the bridge. If you weren't there, the girl still would've died. She had a chance because you were there. That's all we can do.

Speaker: branch
Dialogue: It's twenty-five after. How much longer we wait?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Shit.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: I'm out of gum.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Shit.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Conners, we got a problem.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: We hold. No one move.

Speaker: branch
Dialogue: We can't let him walk.   We have to go now.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: No. Stand down.

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: We're going to lose'em, Conners.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: No. No go. We wait.

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: We bust them now, we got something. But if they get in that car we don't have jack squat.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: We have three cars here and uniformed backup in all directions, if they ride, we'll get them. I want Curtis. We don't go in that house until I say!

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Trigger happy, Sons of bitches!

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: We take them alive!

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: All units, all units. Shots fired! Requesting backup immediately!

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Drop the gun!

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Drop it now. Last warning.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Teddy!?     What's happening?

Speaker: vincent
Dialogue: We got one down. He's dead.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: GUN!

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Gas.  Get out of here!     Get out of here NOW!

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Conners!

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Everyone get down!

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Where's Conners?

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: No!   No, we have to go save him!

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: We can't.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: We have to.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Teddy...

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: ...   If it had to be someone...

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: You sonofabitch.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: Teddy...

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: You've always been jealous of him.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: Jealous?

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: It's because he wasn't only a better cop... He was a better man.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: Detective.     Go home.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: You have something you want to say?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: No, Captain. She said it perfectly.

Speaker: karen cross
Dialogue: Detective Galloway, could you give us a comment?

Speaker: karen cross
Dialogue: We just wanted a statement.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Shame on you.

Speaker: karen cross
Dialogue: This is more than just news for us. American National's CFO sits on the Board of Channel Two. They have a vested interest in what's going on.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Find another source.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Conners was right. We should've never gone in. How many more mistakes can we make in one day? He was eliminating his accomplices. We thought he was going to show up? We didn't even think he could do this... How dumb are we?

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: Detective?

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: I know what they were doing inside the bank.

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: These are today's transaction records from the bank. An average day produces about 400 pages, give or take. Today, there were over 3,000 pages.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Meaning?

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: We've just witnessed the largest heist in history. Somewhere in the neighborhood of a billion dollars.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Come again?

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: It's a computer virus. "The Computer Virus." It randomly withdraws money from all the accounts and deposits it into the bad guys' account. If you check the transactions, no two withdrawal amounts are the same and none of'em are over $100. Most security systems work on the size of the money, not number of transactions. Wire out one million from a handful of accounts and red flags go up. Wire out a less than a hundred from ten million accounts, no flags.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Where's the money now?

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: I tried following one of the transactions. It took me an hour and when I finally had it... It went away.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: How is that possible?

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: The virus created a host of phantom accounts where the money goes

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: It's still moving the money around?

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: Yeah. Any deposit or withdrawal from any bank doesn't usually go into affect until the next business day. So it's going to keep jumping around until it clears at 9 AM tomorrow.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Or 6 AM Pacific time. Sunrise. So why break in? If they're just wiring money? Couldn't they do that from anywhere?

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: That's the regional manager's computer terminal. There's no outside/remote access to it. There you have unlimited entry to the bank's mainframe. No passwords to work around, no "hacking" in. It's all nice and clean.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: A billion dollars is missing and we're only discovering this now?

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: Ironically, when the power went out, it helped hide the virus and bought it time to work.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: So they weren't trying to make   it look like they were robbing a bank,   to rip off a Saudi Prince? They were    making it look like they ripped off a   Saudi Prince to rob a bank.  The Chaos Theory.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Dekker.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Put it through.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: It's not over yet.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: No. My wish is to catch you. You're a murderer. A cop killer at that.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: I know about the money. You steal a billion dollars... They will find you.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: You're still here?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Callo's insignificant.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: That's what he said, Callo's insignificant. But he wasn't.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Lorenz...    Curtis...   Called me.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: He called you?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: He said he didn't kill anyone who didn't deserve it. He said Callo was insignificant. But without Callo he wouldn't have had the knowledge of our department and...  ... He wouldn't have had the front money to hire the crew.

Speaker: jenkins
Dialogue: He was screwing with your head. Go home, Shane. You did good today. Your Dad would be proud. Get some sleep. There will be more bad guys tomorrow.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: I was in bed already.     This couldn't wait til morning.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: How did he come at you, Harry? It's the only thing that doesn't make sense.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: All day long we thought Callo was the dirty cop. All day long we were wrong.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: That's the sign-out sheet from the evidence room. Here's one of Callo's reports. Here's another one... and another --

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: They're not the same signature, Harry. They're not even close.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Maybe he had a cramp in his hand.    I don't know.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: This is your file... You were reprimanded, a month ago after you confronted Callo at the courthouse. You punched him. That ring a bell?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: And I'd do it again. Cops who testify against cops shouldn't be breathing the same air I do. There's a line you don't cross!

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: So you set him up! You forged Callo's signature, you gave him the money and you helped him with his plan because you thought he got a raw deal at Pearl Street Bridge! Don't deny it, Harry cause I know.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: OF COURSE HE GOT A RAW DEAL AT PEARL STREET BRIDGE! EVERYBODY GOT A RAW DEAL!

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You're helping a cop killer, Harry. You're a year from pension. This is how you want to go out?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: My conscience is clean.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: This has been a very long, trying day. And I'm tired. We're chasing a

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Of course he has.   Who knows Conners better than him?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: How the hell does Curtis know Conners better than anyone?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Who would know Conners better than anyone? Who would you protect? And who in your mind got the raw deal at Pearl Street Bridge?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Drop the weapon. Let the girl go.

Speaker: york
Dialogue: That, you don't want to do.

Speaker: john curtis
Dialogue: One step closer and the girl dies.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Think about this... you kill her, where are you going to...

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: It was York who was the bad cop. He assumed Scott Curtis's identity to throw us off the trail.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: York plays his old partner, knowing all his moves, frames his enemy for the crime, kills him too and pulls off the biggest robbery in history.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Do what you want to me. He called to tell me he was going and he's gone and you ain't never going to find him.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Watch me.

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: The number York used to call Harry Hume is a cellphone number. Ran it through

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Can they get a location on him?

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: That particular phone he's using is equipped with the latest GPS technology. Should be able to trace his location within 100 meters or less.  They got him.

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: The signal's coming from around 175th street. That's about fifteen miles north of us.  From the harbor he can take a boat or a sea-plane out. He's gone.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: No. If there's a signal. Means he's still here. He's waiting for something or someone.

Speaker: dax
Dialogue: Waiting? Where? Ain't nothing down there that's open at this hour.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: 175th street... There's is one place.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: I'm going with you.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Detective Galloway...

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: It's not a request.

Speaker: york
Dialogue: Keep the change.

Speaker: pretty waitress
Dialogue: Thanks, mister.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Jason York... this is the police. Put your hands in the air and slowly get on your knees. Do it. Now!

Speaker: york
Dialogue: Don't shoot. You win.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Get down on the pavement!

Speaker: york
Dialogue: I'm cooperating.   You win.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: GET DOWN NOW! FINAL WARNING!

Speaker: york
Dialogue: I SAID... I... GIVE... UP!

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Take the back!

Speaker: york
Dialogue: Was it Harry? It was Harry, right? That fat fuck!

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Let the girl go. It's over.

Speaker: york
Dialogue: Easy for you to say. I'm a plane ride away from a King's Ransom.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Drop the weapon, let the girl go.

Speaker: york
Dialogue: And spend the rest of my days in a cage? Let me ponder...  Don't think so. If you're going to stop me... I'm gonna make you earn it.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: That you don't want to do.

Speaker: york
Dialogue: YOU'D DO EXACTLY WHAT I DID!

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Shit.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: I'm fine.    Go get him.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Which way did he go?

Speaker: pretty waitress
Dialogue: That way.    Down towards the pier.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: FBI's got a team of 40 computer technicians figuring out Lei's virus. They'll break it.

Speaker: york
Dialogue: Your conviction would be admirable, if it wasn't just so sad.

Speaker: york
Dialogue: Get it through your head... The calvary ain't coming. No heroes are coming to save the day. The bad guy gets away at the end of this story.  Dekker peers around the corner... York's gone.  YORK  I think Conners would be sorry that you died. But not me.  Dekker stops, eyes a full 360. The containers all look alike. Dekker wonders if he's just going around in circles. Until...  BAM! BAM! BAM! BULLETS RICOCHET ALL AROUND DEKKER!         He dive-rolls for cover as...  ON TOP OF A CONTAINER... York UNLEASHES, until... CLICK!        Out of ammo.  Dekker, hearing this, pops up, RETURNS FIRE!  York leaps off the backside of the container!  Dekker gives chase. As he circles the container... no York. Instead, he finds a DOCK.  174   EXT.   DOCK - NIGHT                                             174  A narrow wooden dock. There's a few small boats, A TUG BOAT and at the end... A SEAPLANE.  Dekker approaches the tug. Each step slow and deliberate. EYES TRANSFIXED on the seaplane.  As he nears the Seaplane... A SHADOW RISES from BEHIND HIM. From on top of the TUG BOAT!  Dekker turns just as...  York throws a fishing net on top of Dekker.    As Dekker struggles in the net, HIS GUN DISCHARGES!  York with a PIKE POLE in hand, leaps down, CLUBBING Dekker over the head with the weapon. Dekker goes down!

Speaker: york
Dialogue: I have come this far...      I will not be denied.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: We used to spend all day   Sunday just reading in bed. I would    read the paper and he would read one of   his billion books. I didn't deserve    him. I knew that. But I still loved    him.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: He's the only man I ever loved.  Did we all get shot today?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: They said in the city I'd be busy. Every day like this?

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Pretty much.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Great.    I wonder what's next?

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: For me...    a long vacation.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: pretty waitress
Dialogue: Do you think I'm going to charge you after all that? Go on.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: marnie
Dialogue: Do you smell that?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: marnie
Dialogue: When evidence is taken in, any physical mark might effect the ability to lift prints, so, to mark it, we spray it with a scented solution.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Anything else, officers?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You tried them all?/ Nothing for Conners or Lorenz?/ I don't know.        No, maybe he's not on a flight.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Try again.     But try Gleick.   James Gleick.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Conners?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Ten bucks.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Harry and the phone call. He called me, said Callo was insignificant. Threw up a red flag.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: I didn't kill anyone who didn't deserve it.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: All day long, we were trying to find out who the inside source was... it was you.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: The more information you gather, from as many sources as possible, no matter how unpleasant the methods are, the better. And while I'd like to take sole credit it was a team effort.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Teddy's pretty devastated about your death.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Gas.   Get out of here!    Get out of here NOW!

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: So the corpse in the morgue with your name on its toe...?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You're a serial killer.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You said they were all hoods...     what about, Callo?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Callo deserved his fate.      It's his fault.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: This is Callo's fault?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: If it weren't for him, York and I would've never done this. One random act, causes another, causes another, and in the end... the pattern emerges. That's the Chaos Theory.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Lei... you tanked his trial on purpose.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: They should've suspended me after I testified. What did they expect?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: And because the "bitch that made her career off you" worked for Channel Two, that's why American National was the target.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: Everybody who screwed us, got screwed. Everything in its right place.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Why not kill me? You had plenty of opportunities.

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: This wasn't about killing, Shane. This was about standing up for what matters. Besides... you kinda grew on me.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: You're not going to get away.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: All your years of service for not. You're a hypocrite.

Speaker: dekker
Dialogue: Conners?   Conners?

Speaker: stewardess
Dialogue: Good morning, Sir. I'll let the Captain know we're ready.

Speaker: stewardess
Dialogue: Will there be anything else?

Speaker: conners
Dialogue: No thank you. I'm fine.
